Award.AwardTitle: The 50-CCD Tower of DAMIC-M to Search for Light Dark Matter Particles
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dark matter (DM) is ubiquitous yet invisible. It has an enormous influence in our Universe: it binds together galaxy clusters, makes stars move faster around their galaxy, drove the large-scale structure in the galaxies' distribution in the Universe and left an unequivocal imprint in the cosmic microwave background power spectrum. Weakly interacting massive particles (WIMPs), relics from the early Universe, are a compelling explanation chased by sensitive experiments in deep underground laboratories. However, searches for the theoretically-favored heavy WIMPs (about 100 times the proton mass) have been so far unsuccessful. Nor has evidence for such particles been found at the CERN Large Hadron Collider. Alternative scenarios are now emerging, including the existence of a hidden sector of lighter DM particles that can only be observed from their interactions with electrons. The DAMIC program searches for DM candidates beyond the heavy WIMP hypothesis by detecting nuclear and electronic recoils induced by low-mass DM particles in the bulk silicon of charge-coupled devices (CCDs). The DAMIC experiment at SNOLAB is currently in operation and has already established itself as one of the most sensitive detectors for low-mass DM particles. The next step in the program is DAMIC-M: a 50-CCD detector of 1 kg target mass at the Laboratoire Souterrain de Modane (LSM) in France. This award provides funding to support the activities of the DAMIC-M group at the University of Washington.

The activities at UW will bring together a diverse group of participants to collaborate in an international setting in the development and construction of a cutting-edge scientific apparatus. The experience will provide students with the experimental foundation necessary to have a significant impact in a larger collaborative setting as they progress in their careers. The cohort of participants will come from a variety of programs in the Seattle area and the Pacific Northwest that implement active recruitment strategies to enhance diversity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award covers the contributions from the Center for Experimental Nuclear Physics and Astrophysics (CENPA) at the University of Washington to the first two years of the construction of the DAMIC-M experiment, which is expected to take five years total. The DAMIC-M experiment will search for interactions between dark matter particles and ordinary silicon atoms with unprecedented sensitivity. CENPA is responsible for the construction of the CCD array at the heart of the experiment.

DAMIC-M implements a new technology of charge-coupled devices (CCD). The CCDs feature a millimeter-thick silicon target where any free charge generated by an ionizing particle is collected in the CCD pixels. The pixels are then readout by extremely sensitive amplifiers, capable of resolving single electrons. Because it takes very little energy (about one electron-volt) for an ionizing particle to release an electron in silicon, the CCDs are sensitive to very small signals from the interactions of dark matter particles with silicon atoms. In particular, DAMIC-M is uniquely suited to check for the existence of light dark matter particles (with masses between that of the electron and the proton) bound to the Milky Way, which have very little kinetic energy. The positive detection by DAMIC-M of a signal from dark matter particles will provide profound insight into the nature and origin of the dark matter in the Universe.

To achieve its remarkable sensitivity, the DAMIC-M experiment will need to suppress all sources of noise that may interfere with a potential dark matter signal. These include radiation from the environment around the CCDs and instrumental noise generated in the CCDs themselves. For this reason, the experiment must be carefully designed, the CCDs extensively characterized, and the apparatus deployed in the extremely quiet environment of the Modane Underground Laboratory in France.

With this award, CENPA established a facility to test prototype CCDs for the DAMIC-M experiment. The CCDs were carefully handled in a clean room environment and assembled into a “package” that could be connected to a custom electronics controller to read the devices. Of all the characterized devices, those in 6 megapixel format turned out to be the most promising, and a modified 9 megapixel version became the chosen format for the DAMIC-M CCD array. CENPA engineers designed a module that holds four 9-megapixel CCDs. Fifty-two of them are assembled together into the full array. Thermal, mechanical and radioactive background simulations—validated with laboratory data—demonstrate that the design will meet the requirements for DAMIC-M to achieve its science goals.

The research activities at CENPA brought together a diverse group of students, research and technical staff who collaborated in an international context. Three graduate and eight undergraduate students from UW and other institutions (including community college) participated in the project. Three of them were supported by NSF programs Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) and Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP). The students had the opportunity to disseminate their research results in local and nation-wide conferences.
